title: How to Clean a pH Meter Probe

steps.title: Blot the debris off the probe with a chemical wipe.
steps.content: Blot the debris off the probe with a chemical wipe. Try to blot as much of the contaminant off with a chem wipe as you can. Dab the end of the probe gently. [1] X Research source Do not wipe the pH probe or else it will generate static and affect future readings from the probe.

steps.title: Place a beaker under the probe and rinse it with warm tap water.
steps.content: Place a beaker under the probe and rinse it with warm tap water. Use a spray bottle so you have a gentle and controlled stream. Wet the end of the probe with the glass bulb. The beaker underneath will collect the dirty water. [2] X Research source Deionized or distilled water will also work for rinsing the probe.

steps.title: Mix warm tap water with 3 or 4 drops of dish detergent in a beaker.
steps.content: Mix warm tap water with 3 or 4 drops of dish detergent in a beaker. Use dish detergent without abrasives or lanolin. Dawn or Softsoap should work fine. Stir the tap water and soap solution so it is thoroughly mixed together.

steps.title: Soak the sensor in the solution for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Soak the sensor in the solution for 5 minutes. Put the end of the sensor with the glass bulb in the solution. The dish detergent should break down any residue that was not removed during the initial rinse. [3] X Research source Do not stir the probe since it may hit the sides of the beaker and break.

steps.title: Scrub the sensor gently with a soft bristle toothbrush if necessary.
steps.content: Scrub the sensor gently with a soft bristle toothbrush if necessary. Use short, gentle strokes with the brush so you do not break the end of the probe. You can do this while the bulb is soaking or after you remove it from the solution. Stiff bristles will be more abrasive and could damage the reference area of the probe.

steps.title: Rinse the probe with warm tap water.
steps.content: Rinse the probe with warm tap water. Once the probe is clean, use a spray bottle to control the water you use to rinse it. Hold the probe over the waste beaker you used earlier while cleaning. [4] X Research source Distilled or deionized water can also be used to rinse the probe.

steps.title: Use 5% hydrochloric acid (HCl) or vinegar for alkaline contamination.
steps.content: Use 5% hydrochloric acid (HCl) or vinegar for alkaline contamination. For salt deposits or residue that is more tricky to remove, fill a beaker with enough hydrochloric acid or vinegar to submerge the end of the probe. Keep the probe in the solution for 5 minutes before rinsing it with distilled water. Use caution when you work with hydrochloric acid since it is corrosive. Wear protective gear, like an eye shield, lab coat, and gloves. Dab the end of the probe dry with a chem wipe after you rinse it.

steps.title: Make a 4% solution
steps.content: Make a 4% solution of water and sodium hydroxide for acidic coatings. To make a 250 millilitres (8.5 fl oz) solution, combine 10 grams (0.35 oz) of sodium hydroxide with 250 millilitres (8.5 fl oz) of warm tap water. Stir the solution thoroughly and soak the probe for 5 minutes. Rinse and dab the probe dry once you’ve finished.

steps.title: Mix an organic solvent for oil or grease contaminants.
steps.content: Mix an organic solvent for oil or grease contaminants. Organic solvents contain carbon in their molecular structure. Make sure you use a solvent compatible with the sensor material you are using. Soak the end of the sensor in the solvent for 5 minutes. You may need to use a soft bristle toothbrush to scrub any residue away. Organic chemical solvents can be purchased online. Ether and carbon tetrachloride are 2 examples of organic solvents. Detergent should clear up oil contamination, but solvents will give you a deeper clean.

steps.title: Dip the probe into a 4.0 buffer solution.
steps.content: Dip the probe into a 4.0 buffer solution. Submerge the end of the probe into the solution. The numbers on the meter should read close to 4.0 pH, but it may be off by a little bit. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Standardize the pH meter once it reads stable.
steps.content: Standardize the pH meter once it reads stable. The numbers will fluctuate slightly before they stabilize. Once an icon reading “Stable” appears, hit the standardize button to calibrate the meter. Once it’s standardized, you can remove the probe from the solution. [6] X Research source The calibration is fine if the reading is +/- .05 after you standardize the meter.

steps.title: Rinse the probe with deionized water between solutions.
steps.content: Rinse the probe with deionized water between solutions. Clean the probe with the spray bottle. Make sure to rinse the entire area that was submerged so it does not contaminate future solutions. [7] X Research source Blot the probe dry to ensure all the previous solution is removed. Tap water could carry contaminants and should not be used to rinse in between tests.

steps.title: Repeat the process with 7.0 and 10.0 buffer solutions.
steps.content: Repeat the process with 7.0 and 10.0 buffer solutions. Calibrate the meter with the other 2 solutions. This helps the meter have accurate reads for acids, bases, and neutral solutions. The meter will standardize to 7.0 pH and 10.0 pH to match the solutions. [8] X Research source You can skip the 7.0 buffer solution if you want, but including it will give you more accurate reads in the future.

steps.title: Store the probe in the storage solution.
steps.content: Store the probe in the storage solution. The probe needs to be submerged when it’s not in use, so place it back into a storage solution. Ensure that the probe is dry before storing it again so water doesn’t contaminate it. [9] X Research source Do not store the probe in distilled water, deionized water, or tap water since this could contaminate it over time and it will have less accurate reads.
